Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Plaintiff brings this Complaint pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28 and related authority, seeking modification of the Existing Order to change the Parenting Schedule and to impose reasonable limitations and procedures for overnight parenting time to protect the Children’s safety, stability, and best interests.

Barry v. Barry, 419 Mass. 324 (1995) (di.raw_text: Barry v. Barry, 419 Mass. 324 (1995) (discussing standards for modification of custody and best interests).
Barry v. Barry, 419 Mass. 324 (1995) (di.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of a custody or parenting order requires a showing of a material change in circumstances and that modification of the existing order is in the best interests of the child.
Barry v. Barry, 419 Mass. 324 (1995) (di.case_name: Liquor Liability Joint Underwriting Ass'n v. Hermitage Insurance
Barry v. Barry, 419 Mass. 324 (1995) (di.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Barry v. Barry and does not concern custody, parenting plans, or best interests of the child. It is an insurance coverage and duty-to-defend case involving the Liquor Liability Joint Underwriting Association and Hermitage Insurance. Because it does not address standards for modification of custody or parenting orders, it cannot support the cited family-law proposition.
Barry v. Barry, 419 Mass. 324 (1995) (di.relevant_excerpt: The opinion concerns: "The plaintiff, the Liquor Liability Joint Underwriting Association of Massachusetts (JUA), brought an action for declaratory relief... JUA sought to recover from Hermitage defense costs and the amount of a settlement incurred by JUA in connection with a lawsuit against Lamplighter, Inc., a business licensed to serve alcoholic beverages..." This discussion involves insurance coverage and not custody or parenting modification standards.

Driscol v. Driscol, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Driscol v. Driscol, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 902 (1999) (discussing material change requirement and best-interest analysis).
Driscol v. Driscol, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of a custody or parenting order requires a showing of a material change in circumstances and that modification of the existing order is in the best interests of the child.
Driscol v. Driscol, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: Nothing in the provided opinion text concerns custody, parenting time, or modification of family-law orders. The case deals with misrepresentation in a real estate transaction, expert testimony on environmental remediation costs, rescission, and payment of a money judgment into court. It therefore does not establish or discuss the material-change-plus-best-interests standard for custody modification under Massachusetts law, so citing it for that proposition is incorrect.
Driscol v. Driscol, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: Finally, we have serious concerns about the use of an advisory jury in a case in which there are no claims triable as of right to a jury. See Nei v. Burley, 388 Mass. 307, 315 (1983); Delaney v. Chief of Police of Wareham, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 401 (1989); Mass.R.Civ.P. 39(c), 365 Mass. 802 (1974). However, since neither party has raised the issue, indeed they agreed to the process, we leave further discussion of this issue for another day.

Smith v. Jones, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 456 (1.raw_text: Smith v. Jones, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 456 (1997) (parental availability and scheduling as considerations in parenting time).
Smith v. Jones, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 456 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of a custody or parenting order requires a showing of a material change in circumstances and that modification of the existing order is in the best interests of the child.
Smith v. Jones, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 456 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal sentencing/jail credit case and does not concern family law, custody, or parenting time. It never discusses standards for modification of custody or parenting orders, material change in circumstances, or best interests of the child. Therefore it does not provide any authority for the cited custody-modification proposition and appears to be a miscitation or incorrect reference.
Smith v. Jones, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 456 (1.relevant_excerpt: Discussion. General Laws c. 279, § 33A, provides that the sentencing judge must credit prisoners with time served in confinement prior to sentence, while awaiting trial. See also G. L. c. 127, § 129B. It has been frequently stated that these statutes are “not to be examined in an overly technical manner but [are] rather to be read ‘against the backdrop of fair treatment of the prisoner.’” Commonwealth v. Foley, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 238, 243 (1983), quoting from Commonwealth v. Grant, 366 Mass. 272, 275 (1974).

In re Marriage of Smith, 41 Mass. App. C.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of a custody or parenting order requires a showing of a material change in circumstances and that modification of the existing order is in the best interests of the child.
In re Marriage of Smith, 41 Mass. App. C.case_name: Fox v. F & J Gattozzi Corp.
In re Marriage of Smith, 41 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not In re Marriage of Smith, 41 Mass. Because the decision does not address standards for modifying custody or parenting orders, it does not support the stated proposition about material change of circumstances and best interests of the child under Massachusetts law.
In re Marriage of Smith, 41 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: The opinion discusses breach of contract, negligent misrepresentation, unjust enrichment, and the Statute of Frauds in the context of retirement benefits owed to employees; it contains no discussion of custody, parenting time, or modification of family-law orders.

Doe v. Roe, 422 Mass. 123 (1996) (Court\.raw_text: Doe v. Roe, 422 Mass. 123 (1996) (Court’s authority to impose conditions on parenting time to protect the child’s welfare).
Doe v. Roe, 422 Mass. 123 (1996) (Court\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of a custody or parenting order requires a showing of a material change in circumstances and that modification of the existing order is in the best interests of the child.
Doe v. Roe, 422 Mass. 123 (1996) (Court\.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case (a murder and firearms prosecution) dealing with stop-and-frisk, arrest, probable cause, suppression issues, and sufficiency of the evidence. It does not address family law, custody, parenting time, or the standards for modification of custody or parenting orders. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the proposition that modification of a custody or parenting order requires a material change in circumstances and a best-interests finding.
